timeline.bodyText: This bundle is already included as part of jacc-2.0 feature so it doesn't need to be exported again in this auto feature.  Same thing with jaccWeb-2.0 feature.
timeline.author: jhanders34

replies.bodyText: Updated both features to not export this package again.
replies.author: jvanhill

replies.bodyText:
Modified the bundles to be:
io.openliberty.security.authorization.internal.jacc
io.openliberty.security.authorization.internal.jacc.ejb
io.openliberty.security.authorization.internal.jacc.web
replies.author: jvanhill

timeline.bodyText: This should be the API private feature, not the public feature.
timeline.author: jhanders34
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,22 @@
+-include= ~${workspace}/cnf/resources/bnd/feature.props
+symbolicName=io.openliberty.jacc-2.0
+visibility=public
+IBM-App-ForceRestart: install, \
+ uninstall
+IBM-API-Package: jakarta.security.jacc; type="spec", \
+ com.ibm.wsspi.security.authorization.jacc; type="ibm-api"
+IBM-ShortName: jacc-2.0
+Subsystem-Name: Jakarta Authorization Contract for Containers 2.0
+IBM-Install-Policy: when-satisfied
+-features=com.ibm.websphere.appserver.servlet-5.0, \

replies.bodyText: Changed com.ibm.websphere.appserver.servlet-5.0 to io.openliberty.jakarta.servlet-5.0
replies.author: jvanhill

timeline.bodyText: Why did you create a new component instead of transforming the com.ibm.websphere.appserver.api.jacc component?
timeline.author: jhanders34
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,27 @@
+#*******************************************************************************
+# Copyright (c) 2020 IBM Corporation and others.
+# All rights reserved. This program and the accompanying materials
+# are made available under the terms of the Eclipse Public License v1.0
+# which accompanies this distribution, and is available at
+# http://www.eclipse.org/legal/epl-v10.html
+#
+# Contributors:
+#     IBM Corporation - initial API and implementation
+#*******************************************************************************
+-include= ~../cnf/resources/bnd/bundle.props
+bVersion: 1.0
+
+Bundle-Name: JACC 2.0 Service Provider Interface

replies.bodyText: After discussion with the team in Slack, we determined this was the first IBM API we had attempted to transform, and at this time while we have the tools to transform the POM file itself, we don't have the tools to rename the POM file in the transformed bundle. So we are going to leave this project.
replies.author: jvanhill

timeline.bodyText:
I am concerned about the jaccHandlerKeyArray.  Does there need to be jakarta version of those properties instead of the java EE ones.  You can use something like what is done here to help with some of this:
https://github.com/OpenLiberty/open-liberty/blob/integration/dev/com.ibm.ws.concurrent/src/com/ibm/ws/concurrent/internal/ScheduledTask.java#L431
You can have an eeVersion put into your Component to allow you to know if you are doing EE9 or less than EE9.  You can see how to do that in the concurrent project.  If you need help, let me know.  But you can avoid the calling of getMessageContext(InitialContext) and some of the follow on code if it is EE9 or above.
You could also consider to have a second impl of this class where you call a method to do the MessageContext and it does nothing for EE9, but does the old way for EE8 and less.
timeline.author: jhanders34

replies.bodyText: I have made the suggested changes by injecting the JavaEEVersion service into the EJBServiceImpl and setting the EE version in EJBSecurityValidatorImpl.
replies.author: jvanhill

replies.bodyText: You did not address whether you need a second version of the jaccHandlerKeyArray for jakarta.  Have the property names changed in Jakarta EE 9.  Maybe that is something forth coming.  The link I pointed to shows how they handle the different properties depending on version and reading them to support both the old javax... and jakarta... property names.
replies.author: jhanders34

replies.bodyText:
It appears the only key that changed is javax.ejb.arguments as it changed to jakarta.ejb.arguments. I will update the code here.
See https://jakarta.ee/specifications/authorization/2.0/authorization-spec-2.0-SNAPSHOT.html for details.
replies.author: jvanhill

replies.bodyText: I expect that this will change and it will be jakarta.ejb.EnterpriseBean because the spec hasn't been updated yet to remove the javax reference.  Something to follow up with the spec people.
replies.author: jhanders34

replies.bodyText: When ejbCore-2.0 and this function is actually used it will be interesting what the test cases end up doing.
replies.author: jhanders34

replies.bodyText:
I have opened an issue for the spec here:
eclipse-ee4j/authorization#80
I have also made created (#12955) a blocking issue for this PR's parent issue (#11857) to make any changes as a result of work done on the above issue.
I have updated EJBSecurityValidatorImpl.java to set both the ee8- and ee9 keys appropriately. I have also updated PolicyContextHandlerImpl to return the super-set of both the old and the new properties, while retaining the original order. These changes will potentially make it easier for customer to migrate to ee9.
replies.author: jvanhill

timeline.bodyText: Need to look at the generated manifest to see if the JAXRPC is added to the manifest for the Jakarta EE 9 version of the bundle.  If it is, then you may need to adjust the imports to make it optional possibly.
timeline.author: jhanders34
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -16,6 +16,15 @@ Bundle-SymbolicName: com.ibm.ws.security.authorization.jacc.ejb
 Bundle-Description: WAS Security EJB support for JACC Service, version=${bVersion}
 Bundle-ActivationPolicy: lazy
 
+#
+# Produce a JakartaEE compliant JAR.
+#
+jakartaeeMe: true
+jakartaee.transform.jar.name=io.openliberty.security.authorization.jacc.internal.ejb.jar
+JakartaEE-Bundle-Name: EJB support for Jakarta Authorization 2.0
+JakartaEE-Bundle-Symbolic-Name: io.openliberty.security.authorization.jacc.internal.ejb
+JakartaEE-Bundle-Description: EJB support for Jakarta Authorization 2.0
+JakartaEE-Bundle-Version: 2.0
 
 WS-TraceGroup: Authorization

replies.bodyText: With the current version of the EJBSecurityValidatorImpl class, no JAX RPC classes are either imported or exported from the bundle. I will check when I make the changes suggested in the review findings for that class.
replies.author: jvanhill

replies.bodyText: To be clear you are looking for the package, not the class.
replies.author: jhanders34

replies.bodyText:
Yes. Understood. I should have been clearer.
However; after these latest changes I see the javax.xml.rpc.handler;version="[1.1,2)", package imported. I am assuming removing reflection resulted in this package being picked up.
replies.author: jvanhill

replies.bodyText: You can put in the reflection or make it optional I believe.
replies.author: jhanders34

replies.bodyText: Right now none of this code will be called because there is no io.openliberty.ejbCore-2.0 feature for the auto feature to find and cause the auto feature to be used.
replies.author: jhanders34

replies.bodyText: I believe that all the necessary dependent bundles and features exist to create a ejbCore-2.0 private feature like you are depending on.  It is best to hear what @tkburroughs has to say about ejbCore status and if you should make a ejbCore-2.0 as part of this pull request.  None of your ejb tests will currently do jakarta EJB 4.0 since that isn't part of the replacement action yet for JakartaEE 9 and there is no ejbLite-4.0 or ejb-4.0 feature yet.
replies.author: jhanders34

replies.bodyText: Tracy has a PR for that: #12935
replies.author: tevans78

replies.bodyText: Yep, ejbCore-2.0 is nearly ready (pending review comments)... so will be there soon.
replies.author: tkburroughs

replies.bodyText: I have made resolution of the RPC package optional.
replies.author: jvanhill

+-buildpath: \
+	com.ibm.ws.security.authorization.jacc

replies.bodyText:
After talking this over with @jhanders34 and @aguibert , we decided to remove the io.openliberty.jacc.2.0 project and jakartaeeMe the com.ibm.websphere.appserver.api.jacc project instead.
The reason being that currently the jakartaeeMe'd bundles are not published to the local BND repo. Even if they were, that would not resolve issues it would present in Eclipse. This still leaves the issue of the POM files not being updated and renamed but there are several other projects with the same issue that will need to have the same issue resolved.
replies.author: jvanhill

timeline.message: Issue #11857: Create JakartaEE compliant feature for JACC.
Issue #11857: Create JakartaEE compliant feature for JACC.
Issue #11857: Create JakartaEE compliant feature for JACC.

timeline.bodyText: Is PolicyContextHandlerImpl the only possible handler?  By setting both you can get an IllegalArgumentException if the handler doesn't support the key.  If it is a JACC 1.5 handler it won't know how to process the EE9 arguments, so you will end up breaking zero migration.  Also since you know that argument 0 and 1 are the same it seems like a waste to call it for each one of them even if you stuck with this approach.  I think you need to do what you were doing before and just do the first arguments for the spec level.  The jacc provider will have to implement the jarkarta handler and update to do the new parameters anyway.  Maybe have a common array as well if you are going to keep with your current approach.
timeline.author: jhanders34

replies.bodyText:
It is the only PolicyContextHandler Liberty provides.
I had talked to @kwsutter and we preferred to support both sets of properties for ease of use in migration. When I start working on the FATs I will keep an eye on any potential issues that might arise from supporting both, but my suspicion is that the ee8- providers only look for the javax properties so the new properties won't be an issue.
As for the array entries that I am essentially overwriting, the reason I put them in there is because when the spec is updated and we come back and add the updated keys, all we will need to do is update the array and the code to set the key will already be there.
replies.author: jvanhill
